qna.answer: The Reserve Bank, on being satisfied that it is necessary so to do, may declare by notification that all or any of the provisions of this Chapter shall not apply to a housing finance institution which is a company or a group of housing finance institutions either generally or for such period as may be specified, subject to such conditions, limitations or restrictions as it may think fit to impose.

qna.question: What are the provisions of this Chapter overriding other laws?
qna.answer: The provisions of this Chapter shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law for the time being in force or any instrument having effect by virtue of any such law.

qna.question: What is the power to order repayment of deposit in case a housing finance institution fails to do so?
qna.answer: An authorised officer may direct, by order, such housing finance institution to repay any deposit or part thereof in accordance with the terms and conditions of such deposit if it has failed to do so.

qna.question: Who can exempt housing finance institutions from provisions of Chapter under this Act?
qna.answer: The Reserve Bank can exempt any housing finance institution which is a company or a group of housing finance institutions either generally or for a specified period, subject to certain conditions, limitations, or restrictions.

qna.question: What happens if the provisions of this Chapter are inconsistent with any other law?
qna.answer: The provisions of this Chapter shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law.

qna.question: What is the obligation for repayment of deposits accepted by a housing finance institution?
qna.answer: Every deposit accepted by a housing finance institution which is a company unless renewed, shall be repaid in accordance with the terms and conditions of such deposit.

qna.question: Who can direct a housing finance institution to make repayment of deposits?
qna.answer: An authorized officer may direct a housing finance institution to make repayment of deposits if necessary to safeguard the interests of the housing finance institution, the depositors or in the public interest.

qna.question: What is the process for nomination by depositors in a housing finance institution?
qna.answer: Depositors can nominate one person to whom the deposit may be returned in case of death. The nominee becomes entitled to all rights of the deceased depositor, unless the nomination is varied or cancelled.

qna.question: What are the definitions used in Chapter VA of this Act?
qna.answer: Definitions for terms like Appellate Tribunal, approved institution, assistance, borrower, dues, and recovery officer are provided.

qna.question: What is the definition of 'approved institution' in this Chapter?
qna.answer: 'Approved institution' means a housing finance institution which has been granted a certificate of registration under sub-section (5) of section 29A, a scheduled bank, National Housing Bank acting as trustee or otherwise in a transaction of securitisation of housing mortgages undertaken by the National Housing Bank, and such other institutions as the Central Government may, on the recommendation of the National Housing Bank, by notification, specify.

qna.question: What is 'assistance' in this context?
qna.answer: 'Assistance' means any direct or indirect financial assistance granted, by an approved institution during the course of any housing finance activity undertaken by it.

qna.question: Who is considered a 'borrower'?
qna.answer: 'Borrower' means any person to whom any assistance has been given by an approved institution for the purposes of purchase, construction, repairs, extension or renovation of a residential house.

qna.question: What are 'dues' in this context?
qna.answer: 'Dues' means any liability which is claimed as due from any person by an approved institution and includes interest, costs, charges and other amount payable in relation thereto.

qna.question: What powers does a recovery officer have?
qna.answer: A recovery officer can serve a written notice of demand, pass interim or final orders, allow set-off or counter-claims, make interim orders against the borrower to debar him from transferring, alienating or disposing of any property, and take possession of and transfer by way of sale, lease or otherwise any property pledged, mortgaged, hypothecated or assigned to the approved institution as security for any assistance in respect of which default has been made.

qna.question: What is the timeline for disposing of an application made to the recovery officer?
qna.answer: The application made to the recovery officer under section 36E shall be dealt with by him as expeditiously as possible and endeavour shall be made by him to dispose of the application finally within six months from the date of receipt of the application.

qna.question: What are the penalties for a borrower who refuses or fails to comply with an order within the specified time?
qna.answer: Where the borrower refuses or fails to comply with the order within the time specified, the recovery officer may take possession of any property pledged, mortgaged, hypothecated or assigned to the approved institution as security for any assistance in respect of which default has been made and transfer by way of sale, lease or otherwise such property.

qna.question: What is the role of the Central Government in relation to recovery officers?
qna.answer: The Central Government may, in consultation with the National Housing Bank, appoint recovery officers and specify their local limits. The Central Government can also make rules specifying the qualifications for recovery officers.

qna.question: What is the role of the National Housing Bank in relation to recovery officers?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank can make recommendations to the Central Government regarding the institutions that should be specified as 'approved institutions' and can act as trustee or otherwise in a transaction of securitisation of housing mortgages.

qna.question: What is the role of the Appellate Tribunal established under section 36-I?
qna.answer: The Appellate Tribunal established under section 36-I can hear appeals against any decision or order of a recovery officer.

qna.question: What is the role of the court of competent jurisdiction in this context?
qna.answer: If a decree, order, certificate or other authority from a court of competent jurisdiction relating to such deposit is produced before a housing finance institution, the housing finance institution shall take due note of such decree, order, certificate or other authority.

qna.question: Are there any mortgage-related clauses in this document?
qna.answer: Yes, the document includes provisions related to properties pledged, mortgaged, hypothecated or assigned as security for any assistance in respect of which default has been made.

qna.question: What is the time limit for the recovery officer to dispose of an application under section 36E?
qna.answer: The recovery officer shall endeavor to dispose of the application finally within six months from the date of receipt of the application.

qna.question: What powers does the recovery officer have if the borrower refuses or fails to comply with an order?
qna.answer: The recovery officer may take possession of any property pledged, mortgaged, hypothecated or assigned to the approved institution as security for any assistance in respect of which default has been made and transfer by way of sale, lease or otherwise such property.

qna.question: What happens if the dues of the approved institution, together with all costs, charges and expenses incurred by the recovery officer, are tendered to the approved institution or to the recovery officer at any time before the date fixed for sale or transfer?
qna.answer: The property shall not be sold or transferred, and no further steps shall be taken for transfer or sale of that property.

qna.question: Who can assist the recovery officer in taking possession of property?
qna.answer: The Chief Metropolitan Magistrate or the District Magistrate within whose jurisdiction any such property or other documents relating thereto may be situated or found.

qna.question: What is the composition of an Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: An Appellate Tribunal shall consist of one person only (hereinafter referred to as the Presiding Officer of the Appellate Tribunal).

qna.question: What are the qualifications for appointment as the Presiding Officer of an Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: A person shall not be qualified for appointment as the Presiding Officer of an Appellate Tribunal unless he is, or has been, or is qualified to be a District Judge; or has been a Member of the Indian Legal Service and has held a post in Grade II of that Service for at least three years.

qna.question: What is the term of office for the Presiding Officer of an Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: The Presiding Officer of an Appellate Tribunal shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office or until he attains the age of sixty-five years, whichever is earlier.

qna.question: What powers does the Central Government have regarding the establishment and jurisdiction of Appellate Tribunals?
qna.answer: The Central Government shall, by notification, establish one or more Appellate Tribunals, to be known as the Housing Finance Institutions Debt Recovery Appellate Tribunals, to exercise the jurisdiction, powers and authority conferred on such Tribunal by or under this Act. The Central Government shall also specify in the notification referred to in sub-section (1), the areas in relation to which the Appellate Tribunal may exercise jurisdiction.

qna.question: What powers does the recovery officer have to debar a borrower from transferring, alienating or otherwise dealing with property?
qna.answer: The recovery officer may make an interim order (whether by way of injunction or stay or attachment) against the borrower to debar him from transferring, alienating or otherwise dealing with or disposing of, any property which is pledged, mortgaged, hypothecated or assigned to the approved institution as security for the dues.

qna.question: What happens to the costs, charges, and expenses incurred by the recovery officer?
qna.answer: Any costs, charges, expenses which in the opinion of the recovery officer have been properly incurred by him as incidental thereto, shall be recoverable from the borrower and the money which is received by it shall, in the absence of any contract to the contrary, be held by it in trust to be applied firstly, in payment of such costs, charges and expenses and secondly, in discharge of debt, due to the approved institution, and the residue of the money so received shall be paid to the person entitled thereto.

qna.question: Who appoints the Presiding Officer of an Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: The Central Government.

qna.question: How long does the Presiding Officer of an Appellate Tribunal serve?
qna.answer: The Presiding Officer serves for a term of five years or until they reach the age of 65, whichever is earlier.

qna.question: Who provides staff to the Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: The Central Government.

qna.question: What are the salaries and allowances of the Presiding Officer of an Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: The salary and allowances are specified by rules made under this Act.

qna.question: How is a vacancy in the office of the Presiding Officer filled?
qna.answer: Another person is appointed to fill the vacancy in accordance with the provisions of this Act.

qna.question: Can the Presiding Officer resign before their term ends?
qna.answer: The Presiding Officer may resign, but they must continue to hold office for at least three months after giving notice unless permitted to relinquish sooner.

qna.question: How can the Presiding Officer be removed from office?
qna.answer: The Presiding Officer can only be removed by an order made by the Central Government on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity after an enquiry made by a Judge of a High Court.

qna.question: What jurisdiction does an Appellate Tribunal have?
qna.answer: An Appellate Tribunal has the jurisdiction to entertain appeals against any order made or deemed to have been made by the recovery officer under this Act.

qna.question: Who can file an appeal to the Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: Any person aggrieved by an order made or deemed to have been made by the recovery officer under this Chapter can file an appeal.

qna.question: What is the time limit for filing an appeal to the Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: The appeal must be filed within 45 days from the date of receiving a copy of the order, but the Appellate Tribunal may entertain an appeal after the expiry of this period if there is sufficient cause.

qna.question: What percentage of the amount due from a borrower must be deposited with the Appellate Tribunal to entertain an appeal?
qna.answer: 75% of the amount due from the borrower as determined by the recovery officer.

qna.question: What is the jurisdiction, powers, and authority of the Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: An Appellate Tribunal shall exercise the jurisdiction, powers, and authority to entertain appeals against any order made or deemed to have been made by the recovery officer under this Act.

qna.question: Who can file an appeal against an order made by the recovery officer?
qna.answer: Any person aggrieved by an order made or deemed to have been made by the recovery officer under this Chapter may prefer an appeal to an Appellate Tribunal having jurisdiction in the matter.

qna.question: What is the time limit for filing an appeal?
qna.answer: Every appeal should be filed within a period of forty-five days from the date on which a copy of the order made or deemed to have been made by the recovery officer is received by him.

qna.question: What happens if an appeal is not filed within the specified time limit?
qna.answer: The Appellate Tribunal may entertain an appeal after the expiry of the said period of forty-five days if it is satisfied that there was sufficient cause for not filing it within that period.

qna.question: What is the deposit requirement for an appeal by a borrower?
qna.answer: Where an appeal is preferred by a borrower, such appeal shall not be entertained by the Appellate Tribunal unless such person has deposited with the Appellate Tribunal seventy-five per cent. of the amount due from him as determined by the recovery officer.

qna.question: Can the deposit requirement be waived or reduced?
qna.answer: The Appellate Tribunal may, for the reasons to be recorded in writing, waive or reduce the amount to be deposited under this section.

qna.question: What is the procedure and powers of the recovery officer and the Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: The recovery officer and the Appellate Tribunal shall have powers to regulate their own procedure, including the places at which they shall have their sittings. They shall also have powers similar to a civil court under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

qna.question: What is the limitation for an application made to the recovery officer?
qna.answer: The provisions of the Limitation Act, 1963 shall, as far as may be, apply to an application made to the recovery officer.

qna.question: Who are deemed to be public servants under this act?
qna.answer: The Presiding Officer, other officers and employees of an Appellate Tribunal and the recovery officer shall be deemed to be public servants within the meaning of section 21 of the Indian Penal Code.

qna.question: What is the protection against legal proceedings for actions taken in good faith?
qna.answer: No suit, prosecution or other legal proceedings shall lie against the Central Government or against the Presiding Officer of an Appellate Tribunal or against the recovery officer for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done in pursuance of the provisions of this Act or any rule or regulation or order made thereunder.

qna.question: What is the bar on jurisdiction for courts and other authorities?
qna.answer: No Court or other authority shall have, or be entitled to exercise, any jurisdiction, powers or authority (except the Supreme Court, and a High Court exercising jurisdiction under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution) in relation to the matters specified in this Chapter.

qna.question: What are the general fund and other funds established by the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank shall establish a fund called the General Fund, and may create special funds or reserve funds or such other funds as may be prescribed.

qna.question: Who is responsible for preparing and maintaining the balance sheet and accounts of the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: The Board shall prepare and maintain the balance sheet and accounts of the National Housing Bank in such form and manner as may be prescribed.

qna.question: Who has immunity from legal proceedings for actions taken in good faith under this Act?
qna.answer: The Central Government, the Presiding Officer of an Appellate Tribunal, and the recovery officer.

qna.question: Which courts or authorities are barred from exercising jurisdiction in relation to matters specified in Chapter VI?
qna.answer: Courts or other authorities except the Supreme Court and a High Court exercising jurisdiction under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution.

qna.question: When does the National Housing Bank establish the General Fund?
qna.answer: With effect from a date specified by the Central Government.

qna.question: Who has the authority to create special funds or reserves for the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: The Board, if directed by the Central Government.

qna.question: What is the format and manner of preparing and maintaining the balance sheet and accounts of the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: As prescribed.

qna.question: When are the books and accounts of the National Housing Bank balanced and closed?
qna.answer: On the thirtieth day of June each year.

qna.question: What happens to the surplus funds after 15 years following the establishment of the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank shall transfer the balance of surplus to the Central Government.

qna.question: Who audits the accounts of the National Housing Bank and for how long are the accounts audited for after establishment?
qna.answer: The accounts are audited by auditors appointed by the Reserve Bank for a period of 15 years following the establishment of the National Housing Bank.

qna.question: What information must be provided to the auditors and what is their duty?
qna.answer: The auditors shall be supplied with a copy of the annual balance sheet, examine it together with the accounts and vouchers relating thereto, have access to the books, accounts, vouchers, and other documents of the National Housing Bank, examine any director or officer of the Board or any employee of the National Housing Bank, and make a report on the annual balance sheet and accounts.

qna.question: What happens to the annual accounts of the National Housing Bank after they are closed and balanced?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank shall furnish a copy of its balance sheet, profit and loss account for the year, auditors' report, and a report of the working of the National Housing Bank during that year to the Central Government and the Reserve Bank. The Central Government shall cause the same to be laid before each House of Parliament.

qna.question: Who may examine and report upon the accounts of the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: The Comptroller and Auditor-General of India.

qna.question: What information must the National Housing Bank furnish to the Reserve Bank from time to time?
qna.answer: Such information and returns as the Reserve Bank may require.

qna.question: What annual report must the National Housing Bank make to the Central Government and the Reserve Bank?
qna.answer: An annual report on the trend and progress of housing in the country, with suggestions for the development of housing.

qna.question: What is the obligation of the National Housing Bank regarding annual accounts?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank shall furnish a copy of its balance sheet, profit and loss account, auditors' report, and a report of the working of the National Housing Bank to the Central Government and Reserve Bank within 1[four months] from the close of the relevant year. The Central Government shall cause these documents to be laid before each House of Parliament as soon as possible after they are received (Section 49(5)).

qna.question: What information must the National Housing Bank provide to the Reserve Bank?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank shall furnish, from time to time, to the Reserve Bank such information and returns as the Reserve Bank may require (Section 41).

qna.question: What is the obligation of the National Housing Bank regarding an annual report on housing?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank shall make an annual report to the Central Government and the Reserve Bank on the trend and progress of housing in the country. The Central Government shall cause the same to be laid before each House of Parliament as soon as possible after the report is received (Section 42).

qna.question: Who can examine and report upon the accounts of the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: The Central Government may appoint the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India to examine and report upon the accounts of the National Housing Bank, and any expenditure incurred by him in connection with such examination and report shall be payable by the National Housing Bank (Section 49(6)).

qna.question: What is the power of the National Housing Bank regarding staff appointments?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank may appoint such number of officers and other employees as it considers necessary or desirable for the efficient performance of its functions, determine their terms and conditions of appointment and service, and delegate some of its powers and duties to an officer or officers (Section 43).

qna.question: What is the obligation of directors, members, auditors, advisors, officers, and employees regarding fidelity and secrecy?
qna.answer: They shall not divulge any information relating to or to the affairs of their constituents except in circumstances where it is necessary or appropriate for them to do so. Before entering upon their duties, they must make a declaration of fidelity and secrecy (Section 44).

qna.question: What happens if there are defects in the appointment of directors or committees of the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: No act or proceeding of the Board or any committee of the National Housing Bank shall be questioned on the ground of the existence of any vacancy in, or defect in the constitution of, the Board or the committee. No act done by any person acting in good faith as a director or member of a committee shall become invalid merely on the ground that he was qualified to be a director or that there was any other defect in his appointment (Section 45).

qna.question: What is the effect of an arrangement entered into by the National Housing Bank with a housing finance institution regarding the appointment of directors?
qna.answer: Such provision and any appointment of directors made in pursuance thereof shall be valid and effective (Section 45A).

qna.question: What law applies to the credit information disclosed by the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: Nothing contained in Section 44 shall apply to the credit information disclosed under the Credit Information Companies (Regulation) Act, 2005 (Section 43(3)).

qna.question: What is the power of the National Housing Bank to deputize officers or employees from other institutions?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank may receive or take on deputation any officer or other employee from any institution, including a housing finance institution, for such period and on such terms and conditions as it may think necessary in the interest of the National Housing Bank (Section 43(5)).

qna.question: What is the power of the Board to delegate its powers and duties?
qna.answer: The Board may, by general or special order, delegate to an officer or officers of the National Housing Bank, subject to such conditions and limitations, if any, as may be specified in the order, such of its powers and duties under this Act as it may deem necessary (Section 43A).

qna.question: What is the obligation of the National Housing Bank or Reserve Bank regarding fidelity and secrecy?
qna.answer: They shall not divulge any information relating to, or to the affairs of, its constituents except in circumstances where it is necessary or appropriate for them to do so. (Section 44)

qna.question: What is the declaration of fidelity and secrecy that directors, members, auditors, advisors, officers, or employees of the National Housing Bank or Reserve Bank must make?
qna.answer: They must make a declaration of fidelity and secrecy in the form set out in the First Schedule to this Act before entering upon their duties. (Section 44)

qna.question: What is the exception to the obligation of secrecy for the National Housing Bank or Reserve Bank?
qna.answer: They can divulge information when it is necessary or appropriate for them to do so in accordance with the law or practice and usage customary among bankers. (Section 44)

qna.question: What is the effect of any vacancy or defect in the constitution of the Board or committee of the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: No act or proceeding of the Board or of any committee of the National Housing Bank shall be questioned on the ground merely of the existence of any vacancy in, or defect in the constitution of, the Board or the committee. (Section 45)

qna.question: What is the effect of any act done by a person acting in good faith as a director or member of a committee of the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: Such act shall not become invalid merely on the ground that he was qualified to be a director or that there was any other defect in his appointment. (Section 45)

qna.question: What is the arrangement with National Housing Bank on appointment of directors to housing finance institutions?
qna.answer: Any arrangement entered into by the National Housing Bank with a housing finance institution provides for the appointment by the National Housing Bank of one or more directors of such housing finance institution. Such provision and any appointment of directors made in pursuance thereof shall be valid and effective, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in any law or instrument aforesaid. (Section 45A)

qna.question: What is the indemnity of directors in the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: Every director shall be indemnified by the National Housing Bank against all losses and expenses incurred by him in, or in relation to, the discharge of his duties, except such as are caused by his own willful act or default. (Section 47)

qna.question: What is the protection of action taken under the Act for the National Housing Bank or Reserve Bank?
qna.answer: No suit or other legal proceeding shall lie against the National Housing Bank or any director or any officer or other employee of the National Housing Bank or any other person authorized by the National Housing Bank to discharge any functions under this Act for any loss or damage caused or likely to be caused by anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done in pursuance of this Act or of any other law or provision having the force of law. (Section 46)

qna.question: What is the penalty for making a false statement or wilfully omitting to make a material statement in any return, balance sheet, or other document or in any information required or furnished by or under this Act?
qna.answer: The person shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to fine. (Section 49)

qna.question: What is the effect of any nomination in respect of any deposit, bonds, or other securities with the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: The amount due on such deposits, bonds, or securities shall, on the death of the depositor or holder thereof, vest in, and be payable to, the nominee subject to any right, title, or interest of any other person to such deposits, bonds, or securities. (Section 47A)

qna.question: Who is indemnified by the National Housing Bank against losses and expenses incurred in the discharge of duties?
qna.answer: Every director shall be indemnified by the National Housing Bank against all losses and expenses incurred by him in, or in relation to, the discharge of his duties, except such as are caused by his own willful act or default.

qna.question: What is a director not responsible for?
qna.answer: A director shall not be responsible for any other director or for any officer or other employee of the National Housing Bank or for any loss or expenses resulting to the National Housing Bank from the insufficiency or deficiency of the value of, or title to, any property or security acquired or taken on behalf of the National Housing Bank or the insolvency or wrongful act of any debtor or any person under obligation to the National Housing Bank or anything done in good faith in the execution of the duties of his office in relation thereto.

qna.question: Who is the nominee for deposits, bonds, or other securities with the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: If a nomination in respect of any deposit, bonds or other securities is made with the National Housing Bank in the prescribed manner, the amount due on such deposits, bonds or securities shall, on the death of the depositor or holder thereof, vest in, and be payable to, the nominee subject to any right, title or interest of any other person to such deposits, bonds or securities.

qna.question: What is the punishment for making a false statement in any return, balance sheet, or other document under this Act?
qna.answer: Whoever in any return, balance sheet, or other document or in any information required or furnished by or under or for the purposes of any provision of this Act, wilfully makes a statement which is false in any material particular, knowing it to be false, or wilfully omits to make a material statement, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to fine.

qna.question: What is the punishment for contravening provisions of section 29A?
qna.answer: If any person contravenes the provisions of sub-section (1) of section 29A, he shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than one year but which may extend to five years and with fine which shall not be less than one lakh rupees but may extend to five lakh rupees.

qna.question: What is the punishment for failing to comply with an order made by the National Company Law Tribunal under sub-section (2) of section 36A?
qna.answer: Whoever fails to comply with any order made by the National Company Law Tribunal under sub-section (2) of section 36A, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to a fine of not less than rupees fifty for every day during which such non-compliance continues.

qna.question: What is the punishment for receiving any deposit in contravention of any direction given or order made under Chapter V?
qna.answer: Whoever receives any deposit in contravention of any direction given or order made under Chapter V, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to twice the amount of deposit received.

qna.question: What is the punishment for issuing any prospectus or advertisement otherwise than in accordance with section 35 or any order made under section 30?
qna.answer: Whoever issues any prospectus or advertisement otherwise than in accordance with section 35 or any order made under section 30, as the case may be, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to twice the amount of the deposit called for by the prospectus or advertisement.

qna.question: Who is deemed guilty of an offence under this Act committed by a company?
qna.answer: Where an offence has been committed by a company, every person who, at the time the offence was committed, was in charge of, and was responsible to, the company for the conduct of the business of the company, as well as the company, shall be deemed to be guilty of the offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

qna.question: Who is also deemed guilty of an offence under this Act committed by a company?
qna.answer: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), where an offence under this Act has been committed by a company and it is proved that the offence has been committed with the consent or connivance of, or is attributable to any neglect on the part of any director, manager, secretary or other officer of the company, such director, manager, secretary or other officer shall also be deemed to be guilty of that offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

qna.question: What is the cognizance of offences under this Act?
qna.answer: No court shall take cognizance of any offence punishable under this Act except upon a complaint in writing made by an officer of the National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank, generally or specially authorised in writing in this behalf.

qna.question: What is the penalty for a contravention falling under clause (a)?
qna.answer: Twice the amount of deposit received.

qna.question: What is the penalty for a contravention falling under clause (b)?
qna.answer: Twice the amount of the deposit called for by the prospectus or advertisement.

qna.question: Who is liable for an offence committed by a company?
qna.answer: Every person who was in charge of, and responsible to the company for the conduct of the business of the company at the time the offence was committed.

qna.question: What is the penalty for a director, manager, secretary or other officer of a company if an offence under this Act has been committed with their consent or connivance?
qna.answer: They shall also be deemed to be guilty of that offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

qna.question: Who can file a complaint for an offence punishable under this Act?
qna.answer: An officer of the National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank generally or specially authorised in writing.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty that can be imposed by the National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank for a contravention or default of the nature referred to in section 49?
qna.answer: A penalty not exceeding 10 lakh rupees or twice the amount involved in such contravention or default, where the amount is quantifiable.

qna.question: Who can impose a penalty under section 52A?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty that can be imposed by a court under the Act?
qna.answer: A fine which may extend to twenty-five thousand rupees for every day, after the first, during which the contravention or default continues.

qna.question: What happens to the liability of a housing finance institution when a fine is realised under the Act?
qna.answer: The liability of the housing finance institution to make repayment of the deposit shall, to the extent of the amount paid by the Court, stand discharged.

qna.question: Who can a court impose a penalty under section 52A against?
qna.answer: A housing finance institution which is a company.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty a housing finance institution can be imposed for contravention or default under section 49?
qna.answer: A penalty not exceeding 10 lakh rupees or twice the amount involved in such contravention or default, where the amount is quantifiable.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty for failing to produce any book, account, or other document under this Act?
qna.answer: A penalty not exceeding one lakh fifty thousand rupees in respect of each contravention or default.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty for an auditor failing to comply with a direction given by the National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank under section 33?
qna.answer: A penalty not exceeding ten lakh rupees.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty for failing to comply with a direction given or order made by the National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank under Chapter V?
qna.answer: A penalty not exceeding ten lakh rupees or twice the amount involved in such contravention or default, where the amount is quantifiable.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty for any other provision of this Act being contravened or if any default is made in complying with any other requirement?
qna.answer: A penalty not exceeding one lakh rupees in respect of each contravention or default.

qna.question: What is the timeline for paying a penalty imposed by the National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank under this section?
qna.answer: The penalty should be paid within a period of thirty days from the date on which notice demanding payment of the sum is served.

qna.question: Where can a direction for levying a penalty be made if it is not paid within the specified time?
qna.answer: The direction can be made by the principal civil court having jurisdiction in the area where the registered office or the head office of the housing finance institution is situated.

qna.question: What happens if a complaint is filed against a housing finance institution in a court in respect of contravention or default of the nature referred to in section 49?
qna.answer: No proceedings for imposition of penalty against the housing finance institution shall be taken under this section.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty a person or housing finance institution can be imposed for any other provision of this Act being contravened or if any default is made in complying with any other requirement?
qna.answer: A penalty not exceeding one lakh rupees in respect of each contravention or default.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty for a continuing contravention or default under this section?
qna.answer: Further penalty which may extend to ten thousand rupees for every day, after the first.

qna.question: What is the maximum penalty for contravention or default of regulatory requirements?
qna.answer: A penalty not exceeding one lakh rupees for each contravention or default, and further penalty which may extend to ten thousand rupees for every day during which the contravention or default continues.

qna.question: Who can impose a penalty under this Act?
qna.answer: The National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank.

qna.question: What notice must be served before imposing a penalty?
qna.answer: A notice must be served on the person or housing finance institution requiring them to show cause why the amount specified in the notice should not be imposed as a penalty, and a reasonable opportunity of being heard shall also be given.

qna.question: How long does a person or housing finance institution have to pay a penalty?
qna.answer: The sum must be paid within a period of thirty days from the date on which notice is served.

qna.question: What happens if a person or housing finance institution fails to pay a penalty?
qna.answer: The sum may be levied on a direction made by the principal civil court having jurisdiction in the area where such person ordinarily resides or, as the case may be, the registered office or the head office of such housing finance institution is situated.

qna.question: Can a direction be made to levy a penalty except on an application made by an officer of the National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank?
qna.answer: No, such direction shall not be made except on an application made by an officer of the National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank.

qna.question: What is the effect of a certificate issued under sub-section (3)?
qna.answer: Every such certificate shall be enforceable in the same manner as if it were a decree made by the court in a civil suit.

qna.question: Can any complaint be filed against a housing finance institution which is a company in any court of law pertaining to any contravention or default in respect of which any penalty has been imposed by the National Housing Bank or the Reserve Bank?
qna.answer: No, no complaint shall be filed against any housing finance institution which is a company in any court of law pertaining to any contravention or default in respect of which any penalty has been imposed.

qna.question: What happens if a complaint has been filed against a housing finance institution which is a company in a court in respect of contravention or default of the nature referred to in section 49?
qna.answer: No proceedings for imposition of penalty against such housing finance institution shall be taken under this section.

qna.question: What is the Bankers’ Books Evidence Act, and how does it apply to the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: The Bankers' Books Evidence Act, 1891, shall apply in relation to the National Housing Bank as if it were a bank as defined in section 2 of that Act.

qna.question: What is the procedure for the liquidation of the National Housing Bank?
qna.answer: No provision of law relating to the winding up of companies shall apply to the National Housing Bank and the National Housing Bank shall not be placed in liquidation save by order of the Central Government and in such manner as it may direct.

qna.question: Who has the power to make rules under this Act?
qna.answer: The Central Government may, by notification, make rules to carry out the provisions of this Act.

qna.question: What matters can such rules provide for?
qna.answer: Such rules may provide for all or any of the following matters, namely:- (a) qualifications for appointment as a recovery officer under sub-section (1) of section 36D; (b) the salaries and allowances and other terms and conditions of service of the officers and other employees of the Appellate Tribunal under sub-section (3) of section 36M; (c) the salaries and allowances and other terms and conditions of service of the Presiding Officers of the Appellate Tribunal under section 36N; and (d) the procedure for the investigation of misbehaviour or incapacity of the Presiding Officers of the Appellate Tribunals under sub-section (3) of section 36P.

qna.question: What powers does the Board have to make regulations?
qna.answer: The Board may, with the previous approval of the Central Government, by notification, make regulations not inconsistent with this Act to provide for all matters for which provision is necessary or expedient for the purpose of giving effect to the provisions of this Act.

qna.question: What matters can such regulations provide for?
qna.answer: In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such regulations may provide for all or any of the following matters, namely:- (a) the fees and allowances that may be paid to the directors for attending the meetings of the Board or its committees under sub-section (5) of section 7; (b) the times and places at which the Board may meet, and the rules of procedure that may be followed in regard to the transaction of business under sub-section (1) of section 11;

qna.question: Who can make regulations under this Act?
qna.answer: The Board, with the previous approval of the Central Government.

qna.question: What is the power of the Board to make regulations?
qna.answer: The Board may make regulations not inconsistent with this Act to provide for all matters necessary or expedient for giving effect to the provisions of this Act.

qna.question: What matters can the regulations provided by the Board cover?
qna.answer: The regulations may provide for various matters such as fees, allowances, election of directors, rules of procedure, borrowing in foreign currency, forms of applications and notices, balance sheets and accounts, duties and conduct of staff, establishment and maintenance of funds, nomination, etc.

qna.question: What is the consultation process for making regulations by the Board?
qna.answer: Before the expiry of three months from the date of establishment of the National Housing Bank, the Board may make regulations in consultation with the Central Government.

qna.question: What is the power to give retrospective effect to the regulations?
qna.answer: The power to give retrospective effect to the regulations or any of them from a date not earlier than the date of commencement of this Act.

qna.question: What is the procedure for laying regulations before each House of Parliament?
qna.answer: Every rule, regulation or scheme made under this Act shall be laid before each House of Parliament as soon as may be after it is made, for a total period of thirty days.

qna.question: What happens if both Houses agree to modify or annul the regulations?
qna.answer: The regulations shall thereafter have effect only in such modified form or be of no effect, as the case may be; so, however, that any such modification or annulment shall be without prejudice to the validity of anything previously done under that regulation.

qna.question: Who is qualified for appointment as a recovery officer under section 36D?
qna.answer: Qualifications for appointment as a recovery officer under sub-section (1) of section 36D are to be provided by rules made by the Board.

qna.question: What are the salaries and allowances and other terms and conditions of service of the officers and other employees of the Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: The salaries and allowances and other terms and conditions of service of the officers and other employees of the Appellate Tribunal under sub-section (3) of section 36M are to be provided by rules made by the Board.

qna.question: What are the salaries and allowances and other terms and conditions of service of the Presiding Officers of the Appellate Tribunal?
qna.answer: The salaries and allowances and other terms and conditions of service of the Presiding Officers of the Appellate Tribunal under section 36N are to be provided by rules made by the Board.

qna.question: What is the procedure for the investigation of misbehaviour or incapacity of the Presiding Officers of the Appellate Tribunals?
qna.answer: The procedure for the investigation of misbehaviour or incapacity of the Presiding Officers of the Appellate Tribunals under sub-section (3) of section 36P is to be provided by rules made by the Board.

qna.question: What is the manner in which nomination can be made under section 47A(1) of the National Housing Bank Act?
qna.answer: The manner in which nomination may be made under sub-section (1) of section 47A is prescribed.

qna.question: What is the process for making regulations under the National Housing Bank Act?
qna.answer: Regulations can be made by the Board in consultation with the Central Government before the expiry of three months from the date of establishment of the National Housing Bank. They may also have retrospective effect.

qna.question: What is the role of the Central Government in making regulations under the National Housing Bank Act?
qna.answer: The Central Government shall cause every rule, regulation or scheme made under this Act to be laid before each House of Parliament.

qna.question: What is the power to remove difficulties under the National Housing Bank Act?
qna.answer: The Central Government may, by order, remove any difficulty that arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act. No such order shall be made after the expiry of a period of three years from the commencement of this Act.

qna.question: What is the Declaration of Fidelity and Secrecy under the National Housing Bank Act?
qna.answer: It is a declaration made by directors, members of committees, auditors, advisors, officers or other employees of the National Housing Bank to faithfully execute their duties and not communicate any information relating to the affairs of the bank.

qna.question: What are the enforceable obligations for making rules, regulations or schemes under the National Housing Bank Act?
qna.answer: The Central Government shall cause every rule, regulation or scheme made under this Act to be laid before each House of Parliament.

qna.question: What are the timelines for laying rules, regulations or schemes made under the National Housing Bank Act before Parliament?
qna.answer: Every rule, regulation or scheme made under this Act should be laid before each House of Parliament as soon as may be after it is made, and within a total period of thirty days which may be comprised in one session or in two or more successive sessions.

qna.question: What is the declaration that directors, members of committees, auditors, advisors, officers or other employees must make?
qna.answer: They must declare that they will faithfully, truly and to the best of their skill and ability execute and perform the duties required of them as per their office or position in the National Housing Bank. They also agree not to communicate any information relating to the affairs of the National Housing Bank to unauthorized persons.

qna.question: What is the declaration referred to in Section 16A of the National Housing Bank Act, 1987?
qna.answer: It is a declaration where the borrower agrees that the immovable property specified will constitute security for the assistance sanctioned by the National Housing Bank and that the dues relating to the assistance mentioned above shall be a charge on the said immovable property.

qna.question: What is the Third Schedule of the National Housing Bank Act, 1987?
qna.answer: It is a schedule that contains the declaration referred to in Section 16A of the National Housing Bank Act, 1987.

qna.answer: They must not communicate or allow to be communicated any information relating to the affairs of the National Housing Bank nor will they allow any such person to inspect or have access to any books or documents belonging to or in the possession of the National Housing Bank and relating to the business of the said National Housing Bank.

qna.question: What is the eligibility criterion for a borrower to agree to the declaration in the Third Schedule?
qna.answer: The borrower must have requested assistance from the National Housing Bank, and the assistance must have been sanctioned by the National Housing Bank.

qna.question: What is the role of a surety in the declaration referred to in Section 16A of the National Housing Bank Act, 1987?

qna.answer: The timeline for the Second Schedule is not explicitly stated in the provided document. However, it is mentioned that it has been repealed and amended by the Repealing and Amending Act, 2001 on 3rd September 2001.

qna.answer: The penalties for not adhering to the declaration are not explicitly stated in the provided document.
